ARTICLE.TITLE: Indigenous community celebrates 25 years since landmark Mabo decision
ARTICLE.TEXT:
THE Far Northern indigenous community celebrated the 25th anniversary of the historic Mabo decision with an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander dance showcase.

Kenneth Pau said the wet weather didn’t prevent a crowd of about 1000 from gathering at Lennon Street Park in Manunda to mark the occasion.

The event began with an Aboriginal dance showcase, before Torres Strait Islanders shared some of their traditional dances.

media_camera Dancers from Boigu Island perfrom in the rain perform at the Mabo Day celebrations to showcase Torres Strait Islands dance and commemorate the 25th anniversary of Mabo. PICTURE: ANNA ROGERS

Mr Pau, who was one of the organisers of Saturday’s dance showcase, said it was a great event.

Twenty-five years ago Australia’s highest court overturned the legal doctrine of terra nullius, meaning nobody’s land, that had characterised Australian law in relation to land and title.

media_camera People shelter from the rain at the Mabo Day celebrations to showcase Torres Strait Islands dance and commemorate the 25th anniversary of Mabo. PICTURE: ANNA ROGERS

Eddie Mabo was one of a group who campaigned for land rights, but died months prior to the High Court ruling.

Mr Pau said it was a decision that still resonated with the indigenous community and it was amazing that so many people came to acknowledge the 25-year anniversary.
